importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and progress of the Reefline project as a live, evolving initiative in the Miami Beach area.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with full realization anticipated by around 2035, reflecting long-term ecological and cultural investment in marine restoration.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef project off Miami Beach, combining marine art and coral restoration to revive a historically lost reef habitat.
The project features underwater concrete sculptures, including 22 cast cars designed to serve as coral substrates, and will eventually be transformed by growing soft corals like gorgonians.
Colin Foord, a coral scientist and founder of Coral Morphologic, oversees the cultivation of over 2,000 coral specimens for transplantation.
Ximena Caminos, an arts curator from Argentina, is the artistic director and cultural placemaker behind the project, aiming to create ecotourism and public access to marine life.
The project is funded partly by a $5 million city bond approved by Miami Beach voters and seeks an additional $6 million for its first phase.
The project will include an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs and may eventually feature 57 giant starfish sculptures as a symbolic urban landmark.
Reefline aims to restore a natural reef that was historically present in Miami Beach but was buried by sand in the 1970s.
The project integrates art, science, and environmental restoration, positioning it as a model for community-driven ecological innovation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef initiative that combines marine art, coral restoration, and ecotourism. Led by artist and cultural placemaker Ximena Caminos and marine biologist Colin Foord, the project features underwater sculptures—including 22 concrete cars designed as coral habitats—crafted from marine-grade concrete. The corals, including resilient gorgonians, are grown in nurseries and transplanted to the reef, which will be located about 700 feet offshore in 15 to 20 feet of water, accessible to divers and snorkelers. The project aims to restore a historic coral reef that was buried in the 1970s and is funded in part by a $5 million city bond with additional funding goals. It also includes an onshore marine learning center and may eventually feature 57 giant starfish sculptures as a symbolic urban landmark. The initiative blends science, art, and community engagement to create a sustainable, publicly accessible underwater ecosystem.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
